snippet: The region approached a breaking point on Friday as the collective spirit that prevailed in the first few days after Hurricane Sandy gave way to angry complaints of neglect and unequal treatment.
abstract: Emotions of storm victims in New York City approach a breaking point as the collective spirit that buoyed the region in the days after Hurricane Sandy gives way to angry complaints of neglect and unequal treatment; Mayor Michael R Bloomberg, facing widespread criticism, reverses an initial decision and cancels the New York City Marathon.

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON and KEN BELSON
byline.contributor: Reporting on the storm was contributed by Russ Buettner, Annie Correal, Alison Leigh Cowan, Sheri Fink, Joseph Goldstein, J. David Goodman, Denise Grady, Michael M. Grynbaum, Christine Hauser, Winnie Hu, Randy Leonard, William K. Rashbaum, Ray Rivera, Liz Robbins, Nate Schweber, Michael Schwirtz, Kirk Semple, Stacey Stowe, Rebecca White, Michael Wilson and Vivian Yee.

lead_paragraph: The region approached a breaking point on Friday as the collective spirit that prevailed in the first few days after Hurricane Sandy gave way to angry complaints of neglect and unequal treatment.

headline.sub: Bloomberg Calls Off Marathon After Days of Wide Opposition
headline.main: Hardship Strains Emotions in New York
headline.print_headline: Emotions Fray As Danger Grows With Hardships
